title: Aramco finally firms up plans for in December stock exchange listing
text:
State-controlled oil giant Saudi Aramco is set to list on Riyadh's stock exchange in December, the Saudi television channel Al-Arabiya has reported.

Aramco - which suffered drone attacks last month - has delayed the listing several times since Prince Mohammed bin Salman first announced his intentions three years ago.

He hopes for an optimistic $2trillion (£1.5trillion) valuation for Aramco, although some banks and analysts have suggested the figure is highly inflated.

Drone attacks: Aramco's oil production facilities were hit in mid September, cutting the Saudi Arabia's output in half

That would raise up to $20billion (£15.6billion) as Aramco looks to float between 1 and 2 per cent stake.

The oil company is set to announce the plans this Sunday, launch its initial public offering on December 4th and start trading on the local stock market, the Tadawul, on December 11th, according to Al-Arabiya.

Aramco produces 10million barrels of crude oil a day and provides 10 per cent of global demand.

When drones attacked two of its oil production facilities in mid September - which cut the Kingdom's oil output in half - the price of oil soared by almost 20 per cent to just under $72 a barrel.

Prince Mohammed bin Salman first announced his intentions to float part of Aramco three years ago

However, economic worries, the trade war between China and the US and increased crude oil production by the US has depressed energy prices.

The price of Brent Crude is down 1.1 per cent at $60.88 a barrel today.

After listing its shares at home, Aramco is expected to go ahead with an international float in either 2020 or 2021.

London was seen as a favourite for the float when Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman visited last year, but Brexit concerns are said to have caused the company to lean towards other cities.
